chunks.text: a small rounded head and slender neck set on
It is between {{convert|10|and|13|cm|in}} long, with an average [[wingspan]] of around {{convert|19|cm|in}} and a weight of {{convert|9.5|g|oz}}.
<ref name="HANZAB"/> It has relatively long, pointed wings
which has been attributed to its feeding behaviour of flying between shrubs and hovering over flowers.<ref name = "Ford"/>
ales are black and white, with a black head, neck, wings and upperparts, and a black stripe running down from the centre of the chest to the abdomen, and with

The female’s crown, ear coverts and upper parts are buff brown, scalloped paler, with a pale eyebrow, and the chest is speckled grey-brown grading into a dull white belly.  In both male and female the iris is dark brown and the bill and legs blackish brown.  Immature birds are similar to the adult female,
however the upper breast and throat tend to be more uniform
the base of the bill is paler
<ref name="Longmore">{{Cite book| last = Longmore| first = Wayne| title = Honeyeaters and their Allies of Australia| publisher = Harper Collins|

egions in Western Australia. However favourable conditions may result in it breeding anywhere
The black honeyeater is usually encountered alone or in pairs, though up to 50 may gather at stands of plants in flower.<ref name="HANZAB"/>

period is around sixteen days, and the
On hatching, the young birds' eyes are closed, and they are naked except for tufts of
on the head, nape and back.<ref name="Milne"/>
Both sexes feed and care for the young,<ref name="backyardbirds"/> taking all
the insects for the young birds
At one nest, two small young were fed every ten minutes or so, with the male bringing food three to four times more often than the female.
All birds leave the vicinity of the nesting site within a few days of the young fledging.<ref name="HANZAB"/><!-- cites previous 2 sentences --

===Food and feeding===
[[File:Black Honeyeater male.jpg|thumb|right|alt=Male bird feeds on nectar from a Jacaranda flower|A male feeding in a ''Jacaranda'']]
The black honeyeater feeds on nectar, probing flowers and foliage with its long, fine bill. It is mainly found in the crowns of eucalypts, at clumps of [[mistletoe]] or in shrubs, especially emu bushes ''[[Eremophila (plant)|Eremophila]]''. Observations over a twelve-month period in [[South Australia]] recorded black honeyeaters visiting the flowers of berrigan emu bush, twin-leaf emu bush (''[[Eremophila oppositifolia]]''), lerp mallee (''[[Eucalyptus incrassata]]''), and  holly grevillea (''[[Grevillea ilicifolia]]''). The species was also frequently observed hawking for small insects.<ref name = "Ford">{{Cite journal| last = Ford | first = Hugh A.| title = The Black Honeyeater: Nomad or Migrant? | journal = South Australian Ornithologist  | volume = 27 | pages = 263–69 |

date = July 1978 | issn = 0038-2973 }}</ref> The black honeyeater hovers around flowers, feeding briefly at each one.<ref name = "Morcombe">{{Cite book| last = Morcombe| first = Michael| title = Field Guide to Australian Birds| publisher = Steve Parish Publishing| year = 2000 | location = Queensland, Australia| pages = 268–9| isbn =

chunks.text: }}</ref> It may sometimes form large mixed flocks at food sources, associating with other birds such as pied honeyeaters and [[white-browed woodswallow]]s (''Artamus superciliosus''). Like many other honeyeaters, the black honeyeater catches insects in flight.<ref name="Longmore"/> The male, in particular, flies up to a height of {{convert|15|m|ft|sigfig=1}} to seize an insect in mid-air, and then drop

to a regularly used perch.<ref name="Milne"/>

A study of black honeyeaters at seven sites in [[Western Australia]] regularly recorded breeding females eating ash from campsite fires and often making repeated visits over a brief period of time.<ref name = "Brooker">{{Cite journal | last = Brooker | first = Michael G.  | last2 = Cale  | first2 = Belinda M | title = Some notes on the black honeyeater ''Sugomel niger'' in Western Australia, with special reference to feeding on ash | journal = Australian Field Ornithology | volume = 27 | issue = 4 | pages = 153–58 |

date = December 2010 | issn = 1448-0107}}</ref> It was noted that the birds seemed attracted to the remote campfire with groups of around six hovering around and landing beside the fire, an activity described as similar to "bees buzzing around a honeypot."<ref name = "Brooker"/> After pecking at the ash, some of the females foraged for insects, [[Hawking (birds)|sallying]] from the foliage of nearby Wheatbelt wandoos (''[[Eucalyptus capillosa]]'') before returning for more ash.<ref name = "Brooker"/> The activity of the females approaching the fire ranged from a single peck to sustained feeding for a minute or more. Male birds occasionally landed near the fire, but none were seen to take ash.<ref name = "Brooker"/> Well developed [[brood patch]]es on the birds [[mist net]]ted near the fires, suggest that the females take ash around the time of laying, and throughout the

and feeding period. Wood ash is rich in [[calcium]] and it was hypothesised that the females were eating ash to form [[Medullary cavity|medullary bone]] before egg-laying or to repair a calcium deficit after laying.<ref name = "Brooker"/> When other small birds, such as American [[hummingbird]]s, were recorded eating calcium-rich ash, bones or shell it was suggested that the bones of small species may not be able to store enough calcium for egg production.<ref name = "Adam">{{Cite journal | last = Adam | first = Michael D. | last2 = des Lauriers | first2 = James R. | title = Observations of Hummingbirds Ingesting Mineral-Rich Compounds | journal = Journal of Field Ornithology   | volume = 69 | issue = 2  | pages = 257–61  | date = Spring 1998 | jstor =  4514314}}</ref>

Despite the fact that the population trend appears to be decreasing, the decline is not believed to be particularly rapid; the current population seems to be of sufficient numbers, and the species has a sufficiently large range, for the species to be evaluated as of [[
|species of least concern]] by the [[International Union for Conservation of Nature]] (IUCN).<ref name=IUCN/>

Claire A. Runge and colleagues observed that the black honeyeaters' range across inland Australia contracted after years of low rainfall and showed a slow and incomplete recovery even after several years. They added that although nomadic species such as the black honeyeater may have a large distribution, they are often habitat specialists and hence may only occupy a small area within their range. Thus the

may be underestimated.<ref>{{cite journal | title=Geographic range size and extinction risk assessment in nomadic species | first=Claire A. | last= Runge | first2=Ayesha | last2=Tulloch | first3=Edd | last3=Hammill | first4=Hugh P. | last4=Possingham | first5=Richard A. | last5=Fuller | journal=Conservation Biology |volume =29|issue= 3 |

chunks.text: The black honeyeater may be adversely affected by the loss of the emu bush due to [[grazing]] and [[weed control]] by farmers.<ref name="backyardbirds"/>
